channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.description: September 10, 2025
item.dc:subject: Events

item.title: Paris.pm monthly meeting
item.description: August 13, 2025
item.dc:subject: Events

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Great CPAN modules released last week.
item.dc:subject: Weekly collections

item.title: Specifications, Ambiguity, Contradiction
item.description: Goes beyond coding to dissect problem ambiguities, rare in challenge solutions. Provides multiple implementations to handle edge cases.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Raku Weekly Challenge : Week 330
item.description: A well-written, idiomatic Raku solution that highlights the language’s strengths—typing, dispatch and string manipulation while remaining readable and well-tested.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Clearly the Title
item.description: The post offers clean, practical solutions in two languages making it both educational and accessible.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Clear Title
item.description: Solutions are concise and readable. Emphasizes immutability and expressive transformations.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #330
item.description: Solutions are practical and well-reasoned. Great for learners due to clear problem breakdowns.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Digitless Capitals
item.description: The while loop with a regex and substitution is concise and works as intended. Clever way to remove the last character from the matched non-digit portion.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 330
item.description: The post shines with its regex elegance and Perl idiomatic style, great for anyone looking to level up their one-liner skills. A bit of reinforcement with edge-case handling, explanatory tests, and clarity amplifies the educational value significantly.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Capitalizing on Regular Expressions
item.description: The step-by-step examples for both tasks are excellent and make the logic easy to follow. The rationale for using regular expressions is well explained and the commentary on loop construction demonstrates good code readability practices.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 330
item.description: A great post for Perl veterans who appreciate terse, clever code. Beginners might struggle without comments.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: crunching words
item.description: Clear regex pattern using character classes. Clean ternary operator usage. Proper string manipulation methods (tc, lc).
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Capital Cleared
item.description: Production-grade error handling. Empirical performance data. Thoughtful delimiter selection and comprehensive test coverage.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 330
item.description: Clear, idiomatic solutions. Effective demonstration of Raku's modern features. Practical examples with immediate applicability.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: Clearly Capital
item.description: Clear explanation of Raku’s built-in methods (words, tc). Demonstrates both high-level and low-level solutions. Also includes tests to ensure correctness.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: TWC330
item.description: Both solutions demonstrate excellent Perl idioms. Compact yet readable and good test case coverage
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 330
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Clear Digits" and "Title Capital" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 331
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Last Word" and "Buddy Strings". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.
item.dc:subject: The Weekly Challenge

item.title: MetaCPAN running really well. Thanks!
item.description: MetaCPAN is running smoothly now, thanks to the hardwork of the core team.

item.title: Support Gabor
item.description: The chief editor of the Perl Weekly newsletter is Gabor Szabo. There are 32 people supporting him with 5-10 USD / month via Patreon. Join them now!
item.dc:subject: Sponsors

item.title: Support Mohammad
item.description: This edition of the Perl Weekly newsletter was prepared by Mohammad Sajid Anwar. There are 35 people supporting him with 5-10 USD / month via Patreon. Join them now!
item.dc:subject: Sponsors

item.title: #730 - RIP MST
item.description:
Hi there,

We all know the loss of brilliant mind, Matt S Trout. I am still recovering from it. RIP, my friend.

Every time I come across this: *1983 - 2025*, it reminds me of my birth year *1975*.

MetaCPAN seems to be running smoothly as shared in this post by Dean. Anyone interested in the work done can find the documentation here.

The recently concluded The Perl and Raku Conference 2025 videos are now public on YouTube. Of all of them, one of my favourites is the talk about Dancer2 by Jason Crome.

As you know, we had the development release Perl v5.42.0-RC1 on June 25, 2025. In case you missed it, here is the delta page listing all the changes in the release. A week later, we had the maintenance release Perl v5.42.0 on July 3, 2025. Again, we have a dedicated delta page for this release.

What's your favourite change in this release?

For me, I liked the support for lexical method in the experimental class feature. I'm aware, there are many other importants improvements and bug fixes as well. A big Thank You, to Perl Development Team.

What's next in the pipeline?

Well, if you ask me, I'm still waiting for support for roles in the experimental class feature. I've heard some whispers that it's in the pipeline. I'm glad it has not been pushed aside. I'm hoping the next stable release will bring good news, fingers crossed!

What are you working on these days?

I'm mostly working on AWS related services these days as my day job revolves around them. I'm super excited to be working under the guidance of Andrew Solomon from GeekUni. Whenever I explore something new, I create a public post about my experience, viewing it through the lens of Perl and Python.

It's not always about AWS, my last post was about Lexical Method in Perl v5.42. I know, it's been nearly a month now but I'm currently working on a blog post about AWS Lambda. My experience so far has been a bit mixed. The native support for Perl in AWS Lambda is not as robust as Python's. After spending a few nights on it, I finally gave up. I'm happy creating lambda function in Python and then calling them programatically from Perl and Python.

The most fun part is when the lambda function is stored in an S3 bucket. Then there's another twist, using APIGateway to call lambda function. I use LocalStack (the free version) as a local platform. Unfortunately, the free version doesn't have all the features enabled, but it's still good enough to get my hand dirty.

My go-to CPAN module for all AWS related services is Paws. I must admit, it's been rock solid.

Apart from AWS, I'm also working on blog posts about DBIC, ElasticSearch, Caching and Serialisation in Perl. Some are nearly finished, they just need a final touch-up before going public. You can track all my experiments on my personal blog page.

I noticed a nee section titled "Sponsors" added to the newsletter by Gabor. It did the trick for me and brought in one additional sponsor last week, taking the total count to 35 sponsors. I'd like to take this opportunity to thank each and every sponsor for their generous support. Thank you, Gabor for the initiative!

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter and take extra care of yourself.
item.dc:subject: Editorial
